cards.title: 7/7 anniversary / Emotional reunion for London bomb victim
cards.rawTitle: Emotional reunion for London bomb victim

item.title: Emotional reunion for 7 July London bomb victim
item.trailText: A survivor of the 7 July London bombings has an emotional reunion after she unexpectedly meets with the police officer who saved her life
item.standFirst: A survivor of the 7 July London bombings has an emotional reunion after she unexpectedly meets with the police officer who saved her life by pulling her from the wreckage 10 years ago. Gill Hicks, who lives in Australia, lost both her legs below the knee when she was on board the Piccadilly line train. Her unexpected reunion with Pc Andrew Maxwell happened when Gill Hicks joined faith leaders to promote religious unity ahead of the anniversary at King's Cross

cards.title: North Korean mashups / Kim's shiny happy people go walkabout
cards.rawTitle: Kim's shiny happy people go walkabout

item.title: North Korean mashups: Kim's shiny happy people go walkabout
item.trailText: Alice Wielinga had seen the guidebooks full of permagrinning workers in North Korea. But when she travelled all over the country, real life looked shockingly different. Here are her eerie mashups of lives not lived
item.standFirst:
Alice Wielinga had seen the guidebooks full of permagrinning workers toiling away for their supreme leader Kim Jong-un. But when she travelled all over North Korea, real life looked shockingly different. So she superimposed state-supplied images on to her own shots and made eerie mashups of lives not lived

  • North Korea â€“ A Life between Propaganda and Reality is at Arles photography festival until 20 September 2015

displayImages.caption: All photographs by Alice Wielinga
displayImages.cleanCaption: All photographs by Alice Wielinga

image.caption: All photographs by Alice Wielinga
image.cleanCaption: All photographs by Alice Wielinga

cards.title: TV review / Top Gear, The Good Wife, Odyssey and Not Safe For Work
cards.rawTitle: Top Gear, The Good Wife, Odyssey and Not Safe For Work

item.title: Top Gear, The Good Wife, Odyssey and Not Safe For Work: TV review
item.trailText: Telly addict Andrew Collins reviews the week's TV, waving a solemn goodbye to the Clarkson/Hammond/May model of Top Gear
item.standFirst:
Telly addict Andrew Collins reviews the week's TV. He waves a solemn goodbye to the Clarkson/Hammond/May model of Top Gear on BBC2; assesses the end of the sixth season of The Good Wife on More4; wonders how stupid the makers of Homeland-alike thriller Odyssey thinks we are as it is imported by BBC2; and goes back to his hometown Northampton (or not) in new office comedy Not Safe For Work.

â€¢ WARNING: CONTAINS STRONG LANGUAGE

cards.title: Greek referendum / The Greeks have spoken. What now for the rest of Europe?
cards.rawTitle: The Greeks have spoken. What now for the rest of Europe?

item.title: Three-minute update: the Greeks have spoken. What now for the rest of Europe? â€“ video analysis
item.trailText: Jonathan Freedland and Larry Elliott discuss the possible next moves for the European leaders after the Greek referendum
item.standFirst: Now that Greece have returned an overwhelming no vote in the referendum, columnist Jonathan Freedland and economics editor Larry Elliott discuss the possible next moves for the European leaders. Alexis Tsipras has thrown the ball into Angela Merkel's court, but she is constrained on how far she can concede. And if there are no concessions, must Greece exit the eurozone?

cards.title: Female writers recount internet abuse / You need to be gagged

item.title: 'You need to be gagged': female writers recount internet abuse
item.trailText: Writing online can be a confronting experience. Five Guardian writers and editors describe the reasons why
item.standFirst: Writing online can be a confronting experience. Five Guardian writers and editors describe the reasons why by reading out some emails they have received on social media and email in response to something they have posted

cards.title: Clocking off / How to relax and unwind after work
cards.rawTitle: How to relax and unwind after work

item.title: Clocking off: how to relax and unwind after work - readers' pictures
item.trailText: We asked workers from the public and voluntary sectors to show us how they unwind after work, as part of our project on wellbeing, #ClockOff
item.standFirst: We asked workers from the public and voluntary sectors to show us how they unwind after work, as part of our project on wellbeing, #ClockOff

displayImages.caption: After a dayâ€™s teaching, I find this helps Photograph: ID838256/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Brown dog taking a breather in sunny crop
displayImages.cleanCaption: After a dayâ€™s teaching, I find this helps

displayImages.caption: Diving with a barrel jellyfish. All thoughts of NHS dentistry disappear when you drop below the surface â€“ the only sound is your own breathing Photograph: Danygraig400/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Barrel jellyfish and two divers
displayImages.cleanCaption: Diving with a barrel jellyfish. All thoughts of NHS dentistry disappear when you drop below the surface â€“ the only sound is your own breathing

displayImages.caption: After almost a decade putting fires out I now learn and share how to make them by hand Photograph: Rev0107/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Man blowing on dry grass which is smoking
displayImages.cleanCaption: After almost a decade putting fires out I now learn and share how to make them by hand

displayImages.caption: Unwinding by lying down for 10 minutes in the Alexander Technique semi-supine position can help you let go of stress, backache, tension, re-charge your batteries and set you up for the rest of the day. Of course you can do this at various times of day, which is even better Photograph: HD King/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Man lying on his back on grass with his knees up
displayImages.cleanCaption: Unwinding by lying down for 10 minutes in the Alexander Technique semi-supine position can help you let go of stress, backache, tension, re-charge your batteries and set you up for the rest of the day. Of course you can do this at various times of day, which is even better

displayImages.caption: Moon-gazing relaxes and fascinates me Photograph: Pepptalk/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Moon in dark blue sky
displayImages.cleanCaption: Moon-gazing relaxes and fascinates me

displayImages.caption: I take my mum out. She always makes me laugh, although sometimes for the wrong reasons Photograph: Kuplenko/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Older woman laughing
displayImages.cleanCaption: I take my mum out. She always makes me laugh, although sometimes for the wrong reasons

displayImages.caption: I battle the Loch Lomond hills in Scotland with my husband after work Photograph: MCWoods100/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Cyclist on brink of hill in sunshine
displayImages.cleanCaption: I battle the Loch Lomond hills in Scotland with my husband after work

displayImages.caption: I am an NHS commissioning manager working in a clinical commissioning group. I currently work part-time and although this has advantages it is also difficult to keep on top of the workload. I have to prioritise and be very focused at work. To unwind we often take our children to the Lincolnshire coast. Nothing like flying a kite and running on the beach with your favourite small people to reduce your stress levels, and remind you what life is really all about Photograph: Marianna Hargreaves/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Sunny beach with flat sand and scattered clouds
displayImages.cleanCaption: I am an NHS commissioning manager working in a clinical commissioning group. I currently work part-time and although this has advantages it is also difficult to keep on top of the workload. I have to prioritise and be very focused at work. To unwind we often take our children to the Lincolnshire coast. Nothing like flying a kite and running on the beach with your favourite small people to reduce your stress levels, and remind you what life is really all about

displayImages.caption: This is me looking out from under my pillow. Sometimes after work I need to spend time on my own in bed until my brain has relaxed enough to enjoy being with other people Photograph: Alys Courtney/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Patterned duvet with a small opening revealing an eye
displayImages.cleanCaption: This is me looking out from under my pillow. Sometimes after work I need to spend time on my own in bed until my brain has relaxed enough to enjoy being with other people

displayImages.caption: Cycling across Ilkley Moor is this readerâ€™s answer for combatting stress Photograph: Pere Ubu/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Bike propped up with moorland in the background
displayImages.cleanCaption: Cycling across Ilkley Moor is this readerâ€™s answer for combatting stress

displayImages.caption: My daughter wearing her Dadâ€™s first mindfulness crochet creation. I practice mindfulness as a way of reducing work stress, a friend showed me an article about mindfulness knitting and I applied it to crochet Photograph: Lee Payne/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Smiling baby wearing a brown crochet hat
displayImages.cleanCaption: My daughter wearing her Dadâ€™s first mindfulness crochet creation. I practice mindfulness as a way of reducing work stress, a friend showed me an article about mindfulness knitting and I applied it to crochet

displayImages.caption: Swimming in the Cromarty Firth (all year round) is a definite stress buster Photograph: fatlabradors/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Sunset over the firth
displayImages.cleanCaption: Swimming in the Cromarty Firth (all year round) is a definite stress buster

displayImages.caption: I work with people with challenging behaviour who need quite intensive interaction and I find cross stitch has the right amount of concentration needed Photograph: Carly Masterson/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Tudor rose cross stitch pattern
displayImages.cleanCaption: I work with people with challenging behaviour who need quite intensive interaction and I find cross stitch has the right amount of concentration needed

displayImages.caption: Being by the sea (I am lucky to live in Brighton) totally relaxes me as well as giving me opportunity for one of my other favourite pastimes â€“ photography. I am a NHS community nurse in substance misuse. My workload has increased significantly in recent times and my off duty time therefore, becomes more important Photograph: Sue Tyhurst/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Seagull flying towards sea against dramatic background of orange gravel and blue/grey sky
displayImages.cleanCaption: Being by the sea (I am lucky to live in Brighton) totally relaxes me as well as giving me opportunity for one of my other favourite pastimes â€“ photography. I am a NHS community nurse in substance misuse. My workload has increased significantly in recent times and my off duty time therefore, becomes more important

displayImages.caption: I travel a lot. I have recently been to Turkey and took a hot-air balloon ride over the Cappadocia Valley. Unforgettable experience Photograph: Stanley Dellimore/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Hot air balloons crowding over valley in sunlight
displayImages.cleanCaption: I travel a lot. I have recently been to Turkey and took a hot-air balloon ride over the Cappadocia Valley. Unforgettable experience

displayImages.caption: Part of my walk home from the station is along the New River in Broxbourne. It works itâ€™s magic every time as I walk along it. I can literally feel myself relax and let go of the stress of the day. It also helps set me up for the evening. It reminds me that there is beauty and peace in the world. I work for a London authority, in a multidisciplinary team in connection to homeless prevention, itâ€™s a job that however long I stay at work there is always more to do Photograph: Telwal/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Lush green banks and trees along river path
displayImages.cleanCaption: Part of my walk home from the station is along the New River in Broxbourne. It works itâ€™s magic every time as I walk along it. I can literally feel myself relax and let go of the stress of the day. It also helps set me up for the evening. It reminds me that there is beauty and peace in the world. I work for a London authority, in a multidisciplinary team in connection to homeless prevention, itâ€™s a job that however long I stay at work there is always more to do

displayImages.caption: I took my girlfriend (medical student) on a yoga retreat in the mountains of Rasquera, Spain, as a surprise for doing well in her exams. I had to leave a light on in the tent to take this photo, which resulted in a cloud of blood-thirsty midges spending the night with us, which did nothing for her chakras Photograph: Geoff Marsh/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Tent lit up with starry sky and dark surroundings
displayImages.cleanCaption: I took my girlfriend (medical student) on a yoga retreat in the mountains of Rasquera, Spain, as a surprise for doing well in her exams.
